Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Postdoctoral Research Fellowship award to Dr. Christopher R. Friesen is supported by both the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Office of International Science and Engineering at the National Science Foundation. During the 24-month fellowship, Dr. Friesen will work on a project titled, "The Currency of Compromise: Oxidative stress and energetic demands mediate trade-offs in selected traits in color-polymorphic male lizards," under the sponsorship of Professor Mats Olsson at the University of Sydney, Australia.

Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are natural products of metabolic processes in the cells of all organisms, which may damage DNA, proteins and cell membranes. ROS production may be a physiological mechanism that underlies evolutionary trade-offs between traits such as those involved in securing mates and securing fertilizations. However, it is not known whether ROS production and/or the innate ability to detoxify ROS in the face of increased energetic demands mediate these types of trade-off in any organism. In this project, Dr. Friesen will study these evolutionary trade-offs in a species of lizard (Ctenophorus pictus) which lives only one year and thus sacrifices longevity for reproductive output. The oxidative stress of both males and females will be experimentally manipulated to test whether males with lowered oxidative stress are better sperm competitors, and whether females with lowered oxidative stress can store sperm for longer periods. Furthermore, the correlations between energetic expenditure, oxidative stress, aggression and the production of numerous, high quality sperm will be investigated.

Video dairies documenting the progress of this research will be produced and posted online to engage the general public's curiosity of how science is conducted. This award provides a unique opportunity for a US scientist to collaborate with foreign scientists, and utilize the unique facilities, expertise and experimental conditions available abroad.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I am investigating the genetic, energetic and time constraints that potentially limit the expression and evolution of traits. Investment in traits that attract mates in the face of competition, such as elaborate coloration, may reduce the investment in traits that ensure fertilization success, such as sperm number, motility or velocity.

I, along with my international collaborators from Australia, tested whether traits that increase the probability of a male’s mating success come at the expense of producing lower quality sperm and ejaculates. More specifically, we investigated whether there is a tradeoff between coloration and sperm quality that is mediated by oxidative stress.

Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are natural products of metabolic processes in the cells of all organisms, which may damage DNA, proteins and cell membranes. ROS production may be a physiological mechanism that underlies evolutionary trade-offs between traits such as those involved in securing mates (precopulatory sexually selected traits) and securing fertilizations (postcopulatory sexually selected traits). However, it is unknown whether ROS production and/or the innate ability to detoxify ROS in the face of increased energetic demands mediate these types of trade-off in any organism. In this project, I studied these evolutionary trade-offs in a species of lizard (Ctenophorus pictus) which lives only one year and thus sacrifices longevity for reproductive output.  I assessed how sperm quality, coloration and senescence are affected by oxidative stress, and how a male’s ability mitigate the effects of ROS on one of these traits may negatively affect the other two.  

We found that lizards with higher levels of ROS have slower sperm and lower counts of motile sperm than males with lower ROS levels. Most importantly, we found that the sperm of lizards with a bright yellow “bib” on their chest were the most adversely affected by ROS, which suggests a tradeoff between maintaining a colored bib and sperm quality. We also tested the effects of exhaustive exercise and food limited diet on mating, sperm quality and coloration. When we exercised these males, non-bibbed males’ sperm quality (i.e., velocity) actually improved with exhaustive exercise, however the bibbed-males’ sperm quality decreased.

Given these exciting results, we went beyond my original proposal and have examined the telomeres of these bibbed and non-bibbed lizards. Telomeres are DNA “caps” that prevent the loss of valuable coding DNA during cellular replication. In most species, telomeres shorten with age and stress and are believed to play an important role in aging and eventual death. When we looked at the telomeres of bibbed versus non-bibbed males, we found that bibbed males had shorter telomeres. Furthermore, males that maintained brighter coloration also exhibited greater telomere shortening. These bibbed males lose weight more quickly than non-bibbed males, and show signs of earlier senescence with a lowering of their metabolic rate earlier in life. Again, this suggests a significant cost of bearing bib at the expense of longevity.

As the tenure of my fellowship ends, I have been awarded a postdoctoral position to continue this work. I continue to supervise a PhD student (2014-2017) and an Honors student (2015) working to extend this project. We are now further exploring the role of the bib as signal to attract mates and deter male rivals. We also continue to assess the tradeoff between coloration maintenance, sperm quality, telomere dynamics and aging; and the effects of ROS levels on long-term sperm storage and survival within the female reproductive tract.
